bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Howard Kelly, March, 25, 1905

div1.p: Kean recounts Reed's sickness, death, and funeral.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Howard Kelly, March, 25, 1905
div1.opener:
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
A.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
WASHINGTON.
March 25, 1905.
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1418 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Maryland.
My dear Doctor Kelly:
div1.p:
Major Borden tells me that he has sent you a copy of the medical
history of Dr. Reed's illness, so I presume your object in writing to me was
simply to get my personal recollections of his sickness and death.

On November twelfth he was taken with intestinal pain and discom-
fort, but considered it acute indigestion. He told me he had had at various times
in the past year or two, very similar attacks which always passed off in a day or
two with careful dieting and the administration of a cathartic.

He did not go to bed, but as he was no better the next day I urged
him to consult Borden, which he did, I think, on the fourteenth. Dr. Borden diag-
nosed probable appendiceal inflammation, but as there were no severe symptoms a
prompt operation was not deemed necessary.

On the evening of the fifteenth I was invited to dine with Dr. Reed,
to meet Dr. Gorgas, of the Army, now Chief of the Sanitary Department of the Pana-
ma Canal, but found Reed in bed and unable to come to the table.

On the sixteenth his pulse was normal and his temperature not over
99.5 at any time during the day. He passed an uncomfortable night, however, and
Dr. Borden determined next day to operate in spite of the mildness of the symptoms.
Major Borden has informed you of the condition found, which was graver than could
possibly have been guessed from any of the symptoms observed prior to the operation,
Dr.H.A.Kelly -- #2.
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
and from the discolored and board-like rigidity of the caput coli, Dr. Borden pre-
dicted probable sloughing and a fecal fistula. His prediction was found to have
come true when the first packing was removed. No serious symptoms developed dur-
ing the first three days after the operation, although his pulse was rapid and he
seemed nervous and depressed.

I visited him daily at Major Borden's hospital, where he had been
taken afterfor the operation and saw him every day except on the twentieth, when he
was asleep at the time I called. On the two preceding days he talked about his
condition and his anxiety for his family on account of the inadequacy of the pro-
vision he would leave for their support. I tried to make him take a more cheerful
view of the prospect of his recovery and told him what I had learned in confidence;
that the Secretary of War had put in his Annual Report, which had not yet been
given out, a recommendation that he be promoted to the grade of Colonel. He frowned
and said, “I care nothing for that now.” It was the reply of Launcelot of the
Lake, “Prize me no prizes for my prize is death.” My last interview with him was
on the night of the twenty-second, a few hours before his death, when I took his
daughter, to whom he was tenderly attached, to see her last of him. His extremi-
ties were at that time cold and he was somewhat flighty, but know us both and talked
rationally. When the young girl broke down and had to leave the room to regain her
composure, Reed was evidently much affected and calling me said, “Take her home
Kean, I would rather she should not see me again.”

Dr. Reed was buried with military honors on Tuesday, November 25th,
from St. Thomas Church. The pallbearers were all officers of the Medical Corps of
the Army, being Colonel Calvin De Witt, Majors Louis A. La Grade, W. B. Davis, W.
D. McCaw, J. R. Kean and W. B. Banister. Although it rained continuously there
was a large attendance, including the student officers and professors of the Army
Dr.H.A.Kelly -- #3.
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
Medical School and the Navy Medical School in uniform, a number of general officers
with their staffs, the professors and many students of the Columbian University,
Professors Welch, Osler, Flexner, and other distinguished scientific men from a
distance, and a large concourse of friends.

Dr. Reed was buried at Arlington, on a beautiful knoll overlooking
the Potomac and the city of Washington.

I have not by me a copy of the inscription on the simple but hand-
some monument which his widow has erected over him, but will write to Mrs. Reed to
send it to you if you desire it, together with a description of the monument. I
will also ask Mrs. Reed to send you a copy of the photograph of the bust which she
has. If for any reason she is not able to do so, I will proceed at once to have
the bust photographed again for you. I am somewhat reluctant to have this done if
not necessary, because it would probably involve the taking of the bust down from
its position in the Museum, with the consequent danger that some accident might
happen to it.

Trusting that this account may be satisfactory to you, and that you
will put it into more suitable words, I am
div1.closer: Most sincerely yours, J. R. Kean.
